text: At Giant Swarm we recently finished a large migration as of May from our custom built Kubernetes cluster management solution to Cluster API which involved migrating a large number of enterprise production clusters without downtime And I reckon that might be interesting to some other folks so I thought I'd present a few things about it So thanks to KCD UK for letting me do that and thanks for coming It would be sad if I was here alone I'm going to talk about where we started how we made our decision to go on this journey what the migration itself looked like some fun problems we knew about and some we didn't know about and then there's some reflection on our overall approach share some things we learned and some ideas looking back As a note I am going for more of a coherent story than some sort of company archaeology project So while this might sound straightforward because of the linear nature of PowerPoint it was a multi year journey with a lot of iteration and And for those of you who have not had the misfortune of meeting me I'm Joe Salisbury I work at Giant Swarm as VP Engineering and at some point in the future I'll know what that Today my job is talking to you about some of the stuff we've been up to There are socials if you're into social media So let's dig into where we were at before we started this migration For those of you who have not heard of Giant Swarm before all these bullet points are true We build operate and manage cloud native developer platforms for We deploy and manage software in customers We allow platform teams to focus on differentiating work The idea is to help platform teams be more successful or be successful And towards that on the product side this is what our architecture very roughly looked like a high level view of our Kubernetes as a service product before the migration And you can think of it as a REST API to CRUD Kubernetes clusters There's a REST API layer sort of operator layer and then the infrastructure itself And the operators are the key components here So for example the AWS operator we started in February 2017 So it used TPRs before CRDs It's a long going project And you get one of these sets of boxes installed per cloud region or data center It's deployed sort of as part of the management system And if we just look at the data flow so this is more the AWS case You have an API some custom resources an operator and then some sort of resources under management So the REST API creates a cluster custom resource which describes the desired state of some  The AWS operator reconciling that cluster custom resource into a set of CloudFormation stacks and those stacks then form the actual Kubernetes clusters And we'd have the same for other providers with their own provider specific operator and their own sort of cloud and on prem resources or on prem resources And topologically we set this up in a one management cluster to end workload clusters setup So the management cluster is responsible for managing the infrastructure and the workload clusters are where customer or user workloads are run And we'd run one management cluster per cloud region or data center And then Giant Swarm's running a whole bunch of management clusters And there's no shared infrastructure between management clusters So then there's no shared infrastructure between customers And cluster API to move on This also started in 2017 It's now a fully fledged Kubernetes subproject around having declarative APIs and for provisioning and managing Kubernetes clusters So users include us at Giant Swarm but Red Hat Azure VMware And the idea is towards having Kubernetes operators to manage Kubernetes clusters There's a foreshadowing thing here this is the earliest reference to cluster API that actually Marcus found in the Giant Swarm Slack from when we posted about it in early 2018 just a little bit after it was getting kicked off So none of these links actually work now but the second one is interesting around having an early KEP for cluster API talking about having that declarative Kubernetes style API for managing clusters And this is the sort of architecture of cluster API briefly I've stolen this from their documentation So you see a sort of numbers of types of So supporting multiple infrastructure providers or multiple ways to provision Kubernetes customer resources and then a number of providers that they support I'm not going to go into detail on the architecture of cluster API or specific controllers They have really good documentation and there are variable talks But there are notable similarities in the overall design and feature set You can put a customer resource in and get a Kubernetes cluster out But there are some notable differences in architecture So cluster API has a different responsibility separation between their shared and what they call infrastructure provider controllers than what we had in Giant And they use separate operators for bootstrap whereas we had a sort of shared library in Giant Swarm But topologically there's a similar layout This is roughly one management cluster And then you'd have a number of workload clusters But cluster API does have some more flexibility in terms of networking and sort of which providers you mix and match But at a certain point we realized we were somehow building the same thing There's a shared basic set of There are some features in cluster API we'd like to have and some features we'd have to add But at the least there's some sort of isomorphism between the two systems So I'm going to hand wave over a bunch of internal discussion with an emoji of a Fun fact Does this emoji look weird to anyone This is actually the wrong way around Most directional emojis go from right to left because they are Japanese But in most Western cinematography an onward direction is left to right So this I flipped because it felt really weird to me But I'll move on to the actual talk At a certain point we're largely in the understanding that cluster API we've made the decision it would be the way forwards The major benefits we're looking for were not having to spend as much time developing our own controllers around maintenance or new Kubernetes releases But there's also an improved feature set and new providers We reckoned it would take us in the old system around six months to build out a new provider And we wanted to improve that and sort of increase agility And then the question then becomes sort of how to do it And there's the actual work of getting from the Giant Swarm custom controllers to cluster API And just for some jargon we ended up naming the old legacy product Vintage I wasn't in the meeting And we called the new cluster API product Cappy or Cluster API I'll use that naming from now on because it's ingrained in my brain and I can't call it We were running on three providers So AWS Azure and what we called KVM Which is a sort of custom bare metal solution that used KVM for nested virtualization And cluster API has multiple infrastructure providers And the naming pattern is CAP wild card So cluster API provider for AWS Azure And VMware Cloud Director which is another virtualization product from VMware And we decided pretty early on that we'd have to perform a managed migration for AWS We had a large number of clusters And as a small team we reckoned that prolonging the time we'd have to maintain both systems would be quite painful We actually had had a breaking change previously on Vintage that was very tough and we didn't want to repeat it And we do want to provide as much value to our customer platform teams as we pragmatically can But we decided for Azure and KVM to not perform a managed migration We had fewer clusters and customers sort of on and off boarding at reasonable times And we decided it wasn't worth the the live migration part covers AWS so I'll sort of implicitly talk about that from now on with the other providers as part of the new product line We built them new customers created new clusters and existing customers manually migrated over And migrating from a sort of home built KVM virtualization solution to vSphere sounds horrible So as a fun organizational quirk early on in the journey we organized what we called a Hive Sprint The name is really on the nose for Giant Swarm The aim was to get the company to understand and try out and ideally implement the migration from Vintage to Cluster API So for one whole month we suspended our usual teams and meetings we self organized new structures and just all hacked on Cluster API And we didn't manage to migrate everything in a It took a little longer but it did work well for other reasons We got the whole organization to understand the future direction everyone got in touch and tried things out with Cluster API and it revealed blockers and issues quite quickly And it also kick started a lot of the larger discussions the larger decisions that we could have space for those discussions for And then we followed up with them as development kicked further off We did find unsurprisingly that Cluster API wasn't a 100  fit as a replacement when we picked it up And we also found that different Cluster API providers had different levels of and would then require different levels of investment in terms of development time So this is one of our GitHub issues where we tracked various work towards productionizing Cluster API for our use case And a lot of the time between the high sprint and the migration itself was spent on product development and integration which was actually various pieces of work There isn't any specific large bug fix or intensive feature we had to build It's stability and security fixes and small features and enterprise requirements I like this as an example of how open source projects actually get built with sort of multiple parties collaborating on the project and it's that hard work of a thousand features Let's talk about the actual migration This is the actual sort of meat of it We decided to not mix Vintage and Cluster API in the same management cluster It's more straightforward with CRD management and organizing our operators And in the high sprint we had manually proved you could migrate So when we got to the migration proper we started building that out into a tool which had the actually creative name of Cappy Migration CLI And at a very high level you can understand the migration as moving the Vintage workload cluster from the Vintage management cluster to the Cluster API management cluster and transforming it from Vintage to Cluster API in the process did have some other approaches for handling the migration the CLI this manual tool We thought a lot about an operator to sort of more automatically handle it and then we had some loose ideas around a sort of transparent blue green cluster migration We ended up going with the CLI It was practical with our number of It was pragmatic and fairly straightforward to The operator we reckoned would possibly have been overkill It definitely would have required more development work for complete automation we did have like an order of magnitude more clusters it would have been required but then the whole project takes longer With the cluster migration we explored this least some sort of rough idea of sort of bringing up a second cluster transparently migrating workloads and then bringing it  We have some customers who have very limited IP address space like sort of enterprise so it's just not practical to actually double some of their production clusters As a fun technical problem if you work for HashiCorp you have to legally leave the room at this point In Vintage we had built support for using HashiCorp's Vault for PKI and the provider operators would indirectly talk to Vault to issue certificates and then we distribute them to workload cluster nodes via ignition We were using a separate PKI route for each cluster which has some nice security implications When we migrated or when we were going to migrate we needed to have the same certificate route otherwise things get weird It's essentially a new cluster identity We did know that we were going to use kubeadm for provisioning the clusters and you can give it existing certificate material You can give it a root CA cert and a That's all fine The issue is that Vault won't give you the root CA signing key There's no API route for it Unless you fork and patch Vault to add an API route that bypasses their security model and will give you the root CA signing key At the start of the migration we replaced Vault with our hacked version and used that to pull the certificate material out This is the fun practical things you have to do in these kinds of projects To dig into more detail on the actual migration process I found it best to discuss this in two parts This first part relates to the migration of custom resources and then the second part relates more to the management of the nodes and the resources in the cluster themselves The migration tool takes care of these steps First we have to prepare for the migration We fetch all the cluster custom resources so those custom resources that represent the infrastructure of the workload cluster from the vintage management cluster and then we migrate the secrets to the cluster API management cluster This is what requires the hacked Vault which we switched to earlier We then stop reconciliation of our old controllers so they're not trying to reconcile the state of the cluster back We have a sort of pause annotation for this Now we can provision the new cluster API cluster the CLI can generate the cluster API cluster the cluster API cluster custom resources say that fast and we apply them to the cluster API management cluster This is where the cluster API management starts so I'll break this down into etcd first and then Kubernetes and the control plane and the workers The upper section here represents the control plane nodes and the lower section represents more the etcd cluster but each vertical slice is equivalent With etcd we started with a vintage HA etcd cluster that runs on the control plane nodes and then as one cluster API control plane node starts that etcd member joins the etcd cluster Cluster API's etcd management amusingly then removes the old vintage nodes because it doesn't recognize them and we eventually then remove those nodes themselves The next two cluster API control plane nodes start and they join the etcd cluster We end up with a cluster API HA etcd cluster running on the cluster API control plane The Kubernetes control plane nodes and the Kubernetes workers are somehow symmetrical here With the Kubernetes control plane our CLI tool adds the cluster API control plane nodes to the vintage ELB as they're becoming ready so we always have healthy targets We can always respond to API server requests And then once we have a cluster API control plane running we stop the control plane components on the nodes We cord and drain and delete them And with the Kubernetes workers this is probably the most simple part For each node pool once new workers come up we drain the old workers and delete them and we had some settings in the CLI tool for sort of batch size here for those limited or restricted IP address space environments and it's a sort of ship a thesis vibe so you replace all the planks in the boat and you either have a new boat or the same boat but either way we migrated the cluster and at this point we end up with the workload cluster entirely replaced and managed by cluster API so mission accomplished It's churros time I think it's interesting Excluding the special cases so sort of vaults or generating the new cluster API resources or changing the management cluster it somehow looks like a regular Kubernetes upgrade You replace the control plane nodes with new control plane nodes You replace the worker nodes with new worker nodes As a note if you're into it the networking and DNS of the clusters is actually preserved before and We don't touch that during the We're planning on sort of slowly improving and migrating it over time There's features in cluster API or Kappa to support this And the first few migrations unsurprisingly did expose issues and we found we'd also encounter new issues when we started migrating a new customer so this is the commits over time for our migration CLI tool So for example we had a bug where we ended up with different default node sliders between the vintage cluster and the cluster API cluster which led to different pods in the same cluster showing the same IP address which is super exciting when it Exciting is the word We had a customer who'd manually changed root tables in vintage so when cluster API started managing it lost all the root tables and we had a whole bunch of fun when we started migrating clusters in AWS China because it's AWS China generally we hit a lot of these issues you only see in production or with larger clusters and I think with the CLI approach it's fairly straightforward to It just requires the legwork and we started with a friendly customer started on lower environments and sort of took an iterative approach to these migrations and with the actual migration done for one cluster in a repeatable fashion the job becomes one of customer management and I think account management actually takes a lot of the workload here so this is a screenshot from our calendar for scheduling migrations and there's a fair degree of customer work here like enterprises have wild freezes and stakeholder management With one enterprise customer they wanted a video call for every cluster migration and they had a lot of clusters but thankfully after migrating a few together they gained enough trust and they only joined then for sort of later higher environments and then their big production clusters and amusingly the very last cluster that was scheduled to be migrated ended up actually being deleted by the customer because they realized as they were about to migrate it that they weren't using it so it was fairly anticlimactic at the end but somehow more important to have it done and all migrations were achieved with no data loss and no major production customer workload impact Very specific wording Let's talk about some things we might have learned doing all this we were juggling much more than just the cluster API migration during this time It's several years worth of work and other migrations are going on at the same time You can't stop the world For example we replaced our custom SSH solution with Teleport We moved from this REST API to a sort of Kubernetes API based solution We built out GitOps support It's a bunch of stuff So with my engineering hat on I want to do one thing at a time but I think it's not possible even at this sort of large migration to do it at any realistic scale of company size and you have to sort of embrace that and lean into it a little bit more These slides are all just emojis I'm sorry about the design We were initially worried that an upstream solution would slow our pace of which would then lead to customer frustration I think what we leant into was that we could do whatever we wanted with the custom built solution but that included some sort of bad but quick things but we ended up having a positive reaction from using a fully upstream solution So I think the upstream decisions are made with more consensus They're covering more use cases It's a more flexible architecture and we've already seen the benefits of this Customers have said they've noted smoother upgrades already so perfect great and I think upstream has also turned out to be a source of authority with our customers so we'll sort of explain upstream's direction what they're thinking and that works very well for customers as argumentation It's not just us It's the community And as a personal point I like open source software We're thinking more upstream about the company and that's just personally satisfying With team topologies at a company level there's a balance between keeping existing customers happy and working on the new system So to begin with we had one team that was working on both Vintage and Cluster API and given the degree of work for sort of maintaining Vintage with both priorities in the same team we ended up not developing Cluster API as much as we wanted we ended up having to split the team or making the decision to split the team So one team working on Vintage in a sort of maintenance mode and building that capstone release to launch the migration from and the other team with the priority to work on Cluster API to get it to a migration ready state and I think that's when development really started taking off I think the learning for me here is you can say what you want to do with your migration you actually have to make sure your team priorities match and otherwise it won't happen We did try to start using CapG so Google Cloud and CapO so OpenStack while we were still building out the Cluster API product line We had some customer interest in those providers I think we definitely learned a lot about Cluster API and our integration during that but it was tough and distracted building out from the other products and from the migration as a whole I think the learning here was to not try and reap the benefits of a migration before you've done the migration We were a bit too early with that But we have gotten to a point where new providers aren't particularly scary so we're a lot further with integrating Cluster API into our product as well as supporting and bringing up new providers and it's probably maybe depending on who you ask in the company a matter of weeks to start a new provider now For some reason for example people aren't as keen on VMware nowadays so we're investigating Proxmox and Nutanix as providers or MetalCubed as a replacement for that bare metal VMware based providers I think the sort of crux or one of the most interesting questions we had sort of reflectively was when to replace a custom built solution with an upstream solution because I think very often you can choose an open source project and it will do exactly what you need right You're likely not going to have to add features to Node Explorer for example It's fairly feature complete But I think some of the time especially with more complex requirements the project will be close but won't match 100 and over time the project will develop and mature but it's unlikely to magically solve your requirements without your input And you'll need to do some degree of work and then the questions become when to do that work or I think more interestingly whether your solution is differentiating to and will it remain differentiating in the So I'm going to towards the end really start bringing out large slides those of you not aware of Wardly Maps they're a tool for describing value chains So the x axis which is the one that goes across represents the commoditization of components and the y axis represents visibility to the And it's useful thinking about market evolution and sort of decision making in these kind of spaces So this is an incredibly simplified map of Giant Swarm's We want to provide internal developer platforms that's the most visible aspect to the require a cluster management solution that requires clusters and that sort of requires sort of generalized compute And all these components evolve over time They all move towards the right sorry So for example Kubernetes clusters are essentially a commodity now They weren't in the past right You have to sort of custom build them Now you use EKS It's more of a And I think we've seen the same thing with cluster management systems whereas you needed to custom build them before they're now more productized And as your component becomes more commoditized as it moves further to the right your methods for building or managing that component should probably change right If you're custom building something you're going to be using agile methods If it's a commodity you're probably going to be buying that off the shelf from a And I think the point where it's more practical to replace where it is practical to replace a custom built component with an open source component is when that component moves from custom built to product Because in that space it's more straightforward to have multiple organizations collaborating on shared requirements You will have had multiple parties who have custom built that solution and now want to sort of move up the stack and start differentiating And they can share their learnings in that space Or to put it another way much simpler your company has a limited amount of time to spend on innovation Don't spend it on products that other people have started becoming interested in building together So here's another scary looking diagram I don't understand this so I'm not going to go into detail Xavier and Antonio talked about Edge on Kubernetes yesterday This is basically that This is an architectural diagram of our hybrid or smart factory or industrial IoT platform We run a management cluster in the cloud and like a worker cluster in a factory right at the edge using cluster API And I think since migrating to cluster API we've started being able to build out more functionality on top of our clusters So this is an example of how we managed to make use of an open source project and then start innovating on top Don't look at it too hard because it will give you a So I'll start recapping We originally started with a custom built cluster management solution We then noted that the open source community had solved the same or similar problems And we made the decision to rebase on top of the open source solution I think the migration itself was difficult It required deeply technical work and also sort of leadership buy in and customer management And the whole organization was involved There's definitely second system syndrome But on reflection I think it is or can be a very difficult decision to decide on whether and when to replace custom built solutions with open source Possibly there's some insights from our decision making and outcomes we achieve that can help people in future I think the main note for me is sort of considering how your solutions will commoditize over time and whether they'll be differentiating in future That's the take Remember that word This is my last slide One theme from when I was talking to people in the This is just my holidays To help prepare for this talk everyone I spoke to noted it was very much a team effort from the whole company So this is me saying thanks to everyone who actually did the real work so I can stand here and say lots of things that make it sound like I did anything useful But yeah I wouldn't be able to talk about this if they hadn't done the real work So thanks And that's all Those are all my words If you're on a platform team and you want to do less of this let's talk Yes Thank you Thank you
